'''''Amanita flavella''''' is a species of [[mycorrhizal]] [[fungus]] from family [[Amanitaceae]] that can be found in [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] [[Australia]].<ref name=amanitaceae>{{cite web|url= http://www.amanitaceae.org/content/uploaded/legacy/flavella.html|title=Amanita flavella E.-J. Gilbert & Cleland|publisher=Amanitaceae.org|accessdate=December 26, 2012}}</ref> The species have a convex lemon-yellow coloured [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] that is up to  {{convert|90|mm}} in diameter.<ref name=qldfungi>{{cite web|url=http://qldfungi.org.au/garden-fungi/garden-fungi-what-is-that-fungus-in-my-garden/garden-fungi-amanita-flavella|title=Garden Fungi – ''Amanita flavella''|accessdate=December 26, 2012}}</ref> They can also be yellowish-orange coloured and have crowded [[lamella (mycology)|gill]]s that are pale yellow in colour.<ref name=amanitaceae/> The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is central and just like the cap is {{convert|90|mm}} high and yellowish white in colour. It is slightly [[bulbous]], and is enclosed into a [[volva (mycology)|volva]]. The ring is flared and white coloured.<ref name=qldfungi/> The ring is [[ample]], [[Biological membrane|membranous]], and yellowish in colour. The spores are 8.5–10 [[micrometre|µm]] long and 6–6.5 µm wide, and are white coloured, [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]] and [[ellipsoid]]. The species is similar in appearance to ''[[Amanita flavoconia]]'' and ''[[Amanita flavipes]]''.<ref name=amanitaceae/>
